tagline: Ride the divide between two continents. Literally cross the Mid-Atlantic Ridge.

course.terrain_type: Black volcanic sand and sharp lava rock
course.terrain_surface: Black volcanic sand, sharp lava rock, loose highland roads
course.signature_challenge: The weather. Iceland doesn't care about your race plans. You can experience four seasons in four hours.
course.character: Otherworldly. Black volcanic sand, lava fields, glacier views. It looks like Mars with better air.
key_features: Continental divide crossing (literally between tectonic plates)

suffering_zones.label: Lava Field Entry
suffering_zones.desc: Sharp volcanic rock demands focus. This is where flats happen.
suffering_zones.terrain_detail: Sharp lava shreds tires and skin

suffering_zones.label: Highland Exposure
suffering_zones.desc: Wind and weather hit hardest. No shelter. Nowhere to hide.

suffering_zones.label: River Crossings
suffering_zones.desc: Glacier-fed rivers. Cold water, uncertain depth. Dismount or regret.

course.climate_description: 10-15°C (50-59°F) with extreme variability. Cold + wet + wind. Hypothermia risk is real.
climate_challenges: Iceland can deliver rain, wind, fog simultaneously
Weather changes faster than you can unzip a jacket
Four seasons possible in four hours

biased_opinion.summary: The Rift is gravel racing as geological adventure. The course crosses the Mid-Atlantic Ridge—you literally ride between continents. The terrain is volcanic, the weather is unpredictable, and the landscapes are unlike anywhere else on Earth. This is cycling adventure at its most otherworldly.

logistics.parking: Limited village parking. Carpool or hotel shuttles.

random_facts: Course crosses Mid-Atlantic Ridge—literally between North American and Eurasian tectonic plates
Volcanic terrain looks like Mars with better air
Midnight sun in July means extended daylight
Glacier-fed river crossings require dismount decisions
